titleStmt.title: Native digital edition of the archives around the Pacification of Araucania" (1861–1883).
Documentation
titleStmt.author: Maxime Humeau
Alessandro Chiaretti

publicationStmt.p: Encoding realized during an internship at the University of Chile - Archivo Central Andres Bello in the context of a digital valorisation of its archives in 2022.

sourceDesc.p: Derived from base odd after an analysis of 1 files in file:/home/rayondemiel/Bureau/Stage%20Araucan%C3%ADa/TEI_tranformation/data/
Editing from an automatic processing chain from the result of an HTR with Kraken and eScriptorium process.

div1.head: Guide to the encoding of the digital edition of the archives around the events of the "Occupation of Araucania".
div1.p: This guide aims to detail the encoding used in this automated digital edition from HTR data. The goal of this edition is to allow access to interoperable data, to facilitate their transformation and their scientific exploitation.

div3.head: History
div3.p: Already during the centuries of Hispanic colonization in the then Kingdom of Chile, the Mapuche people maintained a sustained resistance to the occupation of their territories for more than two centuries. The process of independence and the consequent organization of the Nation-State in the first decades of the 19th century, deepened the conflict and, specifically, from the middle of the 19th century, the governments of the time considered it appropriate to settle in the southern part of the territory, a region occupied by various Mapuche groups with relative independence from the Spanish and later Republican order.

In 1861 the Chilean Government initiated a Pacification Plan, under the command of Colonel Cornelio Saavedra, beginning numerous battles of occupation and settlement that lasted more than fifteen years and modified the traditional colonial frontier located in the Bio-Bio Region.

div3.head: History of archives
div3.p: Among the documents that make up this series we find correspondence between the different campaign chiefs, lists of the participating military personnel and the chiefs of the area, expenses and accounts, inventories of supplies, and even maps of the territory in question, among others.
Description by Alessandro Chiaretti realized in July 2019.
A first transcription of part of the collection was made in 2014 by Cecilia del Carmen Ramallo Díaz.

div2.head: Structure of the xml file
div2.p: This edition follows the TEI ALL scheme. The entire file is contained within the TEI root. This is subdivided into two elements: the teiHeader containing all the metadata and the text element containing the encoded textual content of the individual archival units.
A single XML-TEI file corresponds to the digital edition of one to several digitized images grouped around an archival unit.

div3.head: Structure of teiHeader
div3.p:
The teiHeader has been divided into three sets:
They allow to structure the metadata in three blocks of metadata concerning the preliminary description of the xml file and its encoding, the encoding choices that have been made and finally the index of entities.

div4.head: FileDesc
div4.p: The fileDesc allows for bibliographic description across six subsets:

The editionStmt element is mainly used to indicate the different responsibilities assigned in the implementation of this encoding. The titleStmt allows to gather the main information of the initial document (title, author). The extent element indicates the number of digitized facsimiles.

div5.head: SourceDesc
div5.p: The sourceDesc contains the set of documents used in this encoding. Note that the first bibl element is the description of the archival holdings

The identification of the scanned files at the source of the edition is allowed by the idno elements. type caja corresponds to the identifier of the box containing the archival unit and id corresponds to the identifier of the item.

div5.head: encodingDesc
div5.p: The element contains a brief summary of the encoding choices applied and all the software used during the editing process within appInfo.

div4.head: profileDesc
div4.p: The profileDesc is an annotated index to render the different entities present within the document. It is divided into two categories:

div5.head: particDesc
div5.p:
The particDesc is an index of character names invoked within the text. It is structured around organizational and people entities. The persons or legal entities are described through a precise schema (see example). The sex corresponds to the value 1 for male and 2 for female and 0 for unknow or other gender. xml:base indicate the identifiant in VIAF database. The descriptive data comes from a SPARQL query on the data present in Wikidata, but for the moment not for organization entities.
José Joaquín Pérez 6 de mayo de 1801 1 de julio de 1889 Chilean politician and President (1801-1889)

div5.head: settingDesc
div5.p: The settingDesc is an index of places referenced within this digital edition. Each record is necessarily accompanied by an type attribute to indicate its typology and an xml:id attribute so that it can be referenced within the edition. Finally, a note element can be attached in order to provide certain details. xml:base indicate the identifiant in Geonames database. The descriptive data comes from a SPARQL query on the data present in Wikidata.

div3.head: sourceDesc
div3.p: It contains a transcript or other representation of a single source document that is potentially part of a genetic file or collection of sources. More concretely, this element becomes the locus of the description of the original ALTO file by taking over the layout elements and the occluded text.

The set of digitized facsimiles is thus described within the area element by gathering all the attached areas and lines. They are described within the area tag whose types and subtypes from a previous segmentation indicate the typology. All the ALTO coordinates have been kept within the points, thus allowing the possibility of the possibility of exploiting these coordinates directly within the digitized image. Finally the textual content is identifiable among the line element and the associated HTR mask, present in the previous path element.

div3.head: text
div3.p: It contains all the textual data retranscribed from the original facsimiles and the areas recognized within the sourceDesc. The structuring is made from a decision tree according to the typology of the lines and the parent zones. It is divided between the body which gathers the fundamental data, and the noteGrp which contains the exogenous data to the initial content.

The initial text can be divided into the following 4 general groups:
the opening: date, place, address, stamps, introductory greeting.
the body of the text: It contains the whole of the device and the statement issued by the author. They are structured within paragraph described by p.
the closing: it contains the final greeting and the signature of the author
the subordinate notes are indicated within the postscript element

The passage to a new page is indicated thanks to pb, whose corresp attribute refers directly to the surface and thus the facsimile image. Sometimes, the presence of the note numbering the image may be present and is noted within the element fw.

div3.head: Correction
div3.p: There are no corrections for spelling or grammatical errors. The transcription is as original as possible. A post-process HTR correction was performed via spellchecker and Levenshtein's Distance algorithm.

div3.head: Punctuation
div3.p: The punctuation has been transcribed as found.

div3.head: Segmentation
div3.p: The segmentation is done via the kraken segmentation model and restructured from the XML-ALTO files and Segmonto ontology.

div3.head: Normalization
div3.p: Words that are crossed out, illegible or only interpretable have not been transcribed.
